claim: Says U.S. Sen. Ron Johnson "opposes faster broadband internet in small towns" and "got nearly $90,000 in campaign contributions from the telecom special interests."
summary: Dialing up some problems

claim: "As secretary of state, (Hillary Clinton) worked hard to get strong sanctions against Iran's nuclear program" and "got Russia and China to support them."
summary: She was a key player

claim: "The approval of the United States was 20 points higher when (Hillary Clinton) left the secretary of state's office than when she took it."
summary: It rose, but not by that much

claim: Says when an interviewer asked Donald Trump if he treats women with respect, Trump replied, "I can't say that."
summary: Clip ignores key context

claim: Says Donald Trump "cashed in" on Sept. 11,  "collecting $150,000 in federal funds intended to help small businesses recover — even though days after the attack Trump said his properties were not affected."
summary: Trump's building was eligible for the $$

claim: Says Hillary Clinton helped "get done" the Children's Health Insurance Program.
summary: Ted Kennedy got much of credit

claim: Says Donald Trump "said a woman should be punished for exercising her right to choose."
summary: A selective reading of Trump's comments

claim: "Human trafficking is the third-biggest criminal enterprise in the world."
summary: Shaky data, but the ranking is sound

claim: California has "the sixth largest economy on planet Earth."
summary: Adjusted for cost of living, California's economy not as rosy

claim: "The top 1 percent in recent years has earned 85 percent of all new income."
summary: Not exactly on the money

claim: Hillary Clinton and Ralph Northam "label police as racists."
summary: Exaggerated for Clinton; baseless for Northam

claim: "There are fewer people crossing (the southwest) border than in the last 30 years."
summary: By border apprehensions, this is (nearly) correct

claim: "Donald Trump said he was excited for the 2008 housing crash that devastated millions of American families, because he thought it would help him scoop up more real estate on the cheap."
summary: Comments were made pre-crash

claim: Speakers at the Democratic National Convention made "zero mentions of the global terrorist threat posed by ISIS."
summary: Lots of words, none of them "ISIS"

claim: "The top one-tenth of 1 percent now owns almost as much wealth as the bottom 90 percent."
summary: A classic Sanders factoid

claim: Says Donald Trump "believes that states should actually have the right to lower the minimum wage below $7.25."
summary: Seems to give states the all clear

claim: "I wake up every morning in a house (the White House) that was built by slaves."
summary: Not exclusively by slaves, but they had a big role

claim: Says Trump shirts are made in Bangladesh, Trump suits in Mexico, Trump Vodka in the Netherlands, Trump crystal barware in Slovenia and his cufflinks and ties in China.
summary: We check the "made in" labels

claim: "We are the only industrialized nation that doesn't guarantee workers paid family leave."
summary: No national law for paid leave

claim: Says "Donald Trump is a guy who has called for privatization" of the Veterans Administration.
summary: Vets groups divided
